repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
`:[count]fclose[!]` close `count` floating window by zindex sort or `!` close all floating windows

Fix #9663

comment_data.body: better to be `(*(win_T **)b)->w_float_config.zindex - (*(win_T **)a)->w_float_config.zindex` (return value should be either negative, zero, or positive for all three possible comparisons)
for `bang` can use `eap->forceit`
oh get it. thanks for tip
This is a strange place to add this command. It should be next to another command that starts with `f`.

```suggestion
		Close [count]th floating window by zindex order. '!' closes
		all floating windows.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -940,6 +940,11 @@ CTRL-W CTRL-Z					*CTRL-W_CTRL-Z* *:pc* *:pclose*
 		window editing it).  The command fails if any "Preview" buffer
 		cannot be closed.  See also |:close|.
 
+							*:fc* *:fclose*
+:[count]fc[lose][!]
+		Close [count]floating window by zindex sort. or [!] close all
+		floting window.

comment_data.body: thanks. Commands are sorted alphabetically. I did not notice T.T
This should be between `:exusage` and `:file` because this list is sorted alphabetically.

comment_data.body: Seems more conventional to name the `ex_` function using the same name as the command: `ex_fclose`
Is the `grid` arg doing anything important here or could we save a lot of noise in the test by only specifying `float_pos=expected_pos`

doesn't follow our naming conventions

```
buf_d
config_a
```

       end
     end)
+

+      local bufA = meths.create_buf(false,false)
+      local bufB = meths.create_buf(false,false)
+      local bufC = meths.create_buf(false,false)
+      local bufD = meths.create_buf(false,false)
+      local config_A = {relative='editor', width=11, height=11, row=5, col=5, border ='single', zindex=50}

comment_data.body:
"order" seems to be the key word. It's not obvious that the zindex value itself is ignored, what matters is the _order relative to other zindexes_. 

So if there are 3 floats with zindexes 99, 999, 9999:

- `:2fclose` closes the two highest-zindex floats
- `:fclose` closes all floats if cursor is _not_ in a float
- `:fclose` closes the highest-zindex float if cursor is in a float
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -392,6 +392,11 @@ CTRL-W CTRL-O					*CTRL-W_CTRL-O* *:on* *:only*
 		given, then they become hidden.  But modified buffers are
 		never abandoned, so changes cannot get lost.
 
+							*:fc* *:fclose*
+:[count]fc[lose][!]
+		Close [count]th floating window by zindex order. '!' to close
+		all floating windows.

comment_regular_data.body:
Cool to see this!

- The general idea of #9663 was to use `:pclose` and related preview-window features as inspiration. 
    - Presumably we _don't_ need analogs to `:ptag`/`:psearch`/`:pedit`, instead we should implement Vim's `:help preview-popup` behavior.
- Based on `popup.txt` it looks like Vim doesn't have anything similar to `:fclose` for "popups" so we're on our own here.
yes `zindex` sorting needs fix. I will continue it after the other PR is completed.

Possible follow up: We could maintain a vector over zindex sorted floats in `window.c`. similar to `layers` in `ui_compositor.c` but only including floats and always available (also when ext_multigrid is used and compositor disabled) . Then we won't need the `qsort()` in the command  implementation (and also this info could be used elsewhere, i e be queried by some API function).

title: feat(float): add fclose command
